entry.title: Milestone: COVID-19 five years ago
entry.summary: Five years agoÂ on 31 December 2019, WHOâ€™s Country Office in China picked up a media statement by the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission from their website on cases of â€˜viral pneumoniaâ€™ in Wuhan, China. In the weeks, months and years that unfolded after that, COVID-19 came to shape our lives and our world.Â At WHO, we went to work immediately as the new year dawned. WHO employees activated emergency systemsÂ on 1 January 2020, and informed the worldÂ on 4 January. ByÂ 9-12 January, WHO had published its first set of comprehensive guidance for countries, andÂ on 13 January, we brought together partners to publish the blueprint of the first SARS-CoV-2 laboratory test.Â All along, we convened experts and ministries of health from around the world, gathered and analysed data, and shared what was reported, what we learned and what it meant for people. Read about WHOâ€™s actions in this interactive timeline.Â As we mark this milestone, letâ€™s take a moment to honour the lives changed and lost, recognize those who are suffering from COVID-19 and long COVID, express gratitude to the health workers who sacrificed so much to care for us, and commit to learning from COVID-19 to build a healthier tomorrow.Â We continue to call on China to share data and access so we can understand the origins of COVID-19. This is a moral and scientific imperative. Without transparency, sharing, and cooperation among countries, the world cannot adequately prevent and prepare for future epidemics and pandemics.Â As we pose the question, â€œIs the world better prepared for the next pandemic than we were for COVID-19?â€ see WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesusâ€™s response at a recent press conference:Â https://who.canto.global/b/SHEJL

entry.title: Kamal Adwan Hospital out of service following a raid yesterday and repeated attacks since October
entry.summary:
WHO is appalled by yesterdayâ€™s raid on Kamal Adwan Hospital, which put the last major health facility in North Gaza out of service. The systematic dismantling of the health system and a siege for over 80 days on North Gaza puts the lives of the 75,000 Palestinians remaining in the area at risk.
Initial reports indicate that some areas of the hospital were burnt and severely damaged during the raid, including the laboratory, surgical unit, engineering and maintenance department, operations theatre, and the medical store. entry.title: Statement by Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General on the attack on the Sana'a airport, Yemen
entry.summary: Our mission to negotiate the release of the United Nations staff detainees and to assess the health and humanitarian situation in Yemen concluded today. We continue to call for the detainees' immediate release.Â As we were about to board our flight from Sanaâ€™a, about three hours ago (around 5 pm local time), the airport came under aerial bombardment.Â One of our planeâ€™s crew members was injured.Â At least two people were reported killed at the airport.Â The air traffic control tower, the departure lounge â€” just a few meters from where we were â€” and the runway were damaged.Â We will need to wait for the damage to the airport to be repaired before we can leave. My UN and WHO colleagues and I are safe. Our heartfelt condolences to the families whose loved ones lost their lives in the attack.

entry.title: Statement on the antigen composition of COVID-19 vaccines
entry.summary:
Key points:
Vaccination remains an important public health countermeasure against COVID-19. As per the WHO Director Generalâ€™s standing recommendations for COVID-19, Member States are recommended to continue to offer COVID-19 vaccination based on the recommendations of the WHO Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE). SARS-CoV-2 continues to circulate and evolve with important genetic and antigenic evolution of the spike protein since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic. The objective of an update to COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition is to enhance vaccine-induced immune responses to circulating SARS-CoV-2 variants.
